articles.title: What I Learned From a Janky Drone
articles.summary: The package containing the ArduCopter 2.8 board finally arrived from China, bearing the weight of our anticipation. articles.title: Learning More With Less
articles.summary: My name is Engineer Bainomugisha. Yes, Engineer is my first name and also my career. articles.title: The 60-Year Old Algorithm Underlying Today’s Tech
articles.summary: CT scanning, streaming videos, and sending images over the Internet wouldn’t be possible without the Fast Fourier transform. Commonly known as FFT, the computer algorithm designed by researchers at Princeton University and IBM is found in just about every electronic device, according to an entry in ...

articles.title: China, Russia, and U.S. Race to Develop Lunar Nuclear Reactors
articles.summary: China, Russia, and the United States are racing to put nuclear power plants on the moon. China and Russia in May agreed to work together to complete a lunar nuclear reactor by 2036. articles.summary: Video Friday is your weekly selection of awesome robotics videos, collected by your friends at IEEE Spectrum robotics. articles.title: The Unlikely Revival of Nuclear Batteries
articles.summary: In 1970, surgeons in Paris implanted the first nuclear-powered pacemaker, and over the next five years, at least 1,400 additional people received the devices, mostly in France and the United States. articles.title: Does Computing Face a Lean Future?
articles.summary: In July, a University of Michigan computer engineering professor put out a new idea for measuring the efficiency of a processor design. articles.title: Teens’ Innovations Save Marine Life and Better Detect Diseases
articles.summary: Coral reefs are vital to marine ecosystems, supporting more species than any other ocean environment. More than 80 percent of the planet’s coral reefs have been bleached due to rising ocean temperatures and pollution, according to the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. articles.title: Fancy Flying Trick Could Bring Sensors to Earth’s “Ignorosphere”
articles.summary: Earth’s atmosphere is large, extending out to around 10,000 kilometers from the surface of the planet. It’s so large, in fact, that scientists break it into five separate sections. articles.title: It’s the End of the Line for AOL’s Dial-Up Service
articles.summary:
The last time I used a dial-up modem came sometime around 2001. Within just a few years, dial-up had exited my life, never to return. I haven’t even had a telephone line in my house for most of my adult life.



But I still feel a strong tinge of sadness to know that AOL is finally retiring the ol’ ...

articles.title: Trump Seeks to Cancel CHIPS Act R&D Organization’s Funds
articles.summary: The U.S. Commerce Department says it will not abide by an agreement to fund the U.S. CHIPS and Science Act’s R&D through the nonprofit set up to administer the program, called Natcast. articles.title: Data Centers May House AI—But Operators Don’t Trust AI (Yet)
articles.summary: AI is starting to be trusted with high-stakes tasks, including running automated factories and guiding military drones through hostile airspace.
